intro: Brassica repanda subsp. africana, commonly known as the African wild mustard, is a herbaceous plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves and yellow flowers arranged in racemes. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in grasslands and along roadsides. The species is notable for its potential in phytoremediation due to its ability to accumulate heavy metals.
